awd_titl_txt: CIF: Small: Best Wiretap Codes for Real-world Physical-layer Security
awd_abstract_narration:
The pervasive nature of low-power devices in modern communication systems has introduced scores of new and exciting possibilities as well as several challenges in today's continuously connected world. Users now enjoy perpetual accessibility to data and information through various network structures; however, securing personal data has never been more challenging. Due to many networks being comprised of low-power devices (e.g., as in the Internet of Things), low-power secure alternatives to traditional cryptography are currently in demand. One technique that shows immense promise for addressing these needs is physical-layer security with wiretap coding. However, despite the several decades of fundamental theoretical research, the search continues for practical coding schemes that can address the security challenges of modern networks. This project has the potential to be transformative in the field of wiretap coding for physical-layer security. The proposed research targets a straightforward and yet novel approach to wiretap coding that will produce provably-best coding structures over various wiretap channel models. Such codes are likely to direct security standards and protocols adapted to the Internet of Things and other applications. The project seeks to recruit a diverse research team through full inclusion in special undergraduate research and outreach programs at Brigham Young University. Students from the research group will develop skills and professional networks that allow them to go on to build greater diversity in STEM professions.

Key limiting factors in the development and adoption of wiretap coding are: the current design theory seeks codes that achieve secrecy as blocklength tends to infinity, and it is assumed that the designer has full knowledge of the eavesdropper's channel state information. This project seeks to overcome both of these problems by recasting the physical-layer security problem as a joint signaling/coding problem, where signaling and channel sounding provide an environment with high capacity for secrecy, and wiretap coding then maximizes security in that environment through adoption of specific finite blocklength wiretap codes. The approach requires the research team to find the best codes for all possible states of the eavesdropper's channel. This project addresses the coding side of the joint design problem, and will identify fundamental limits of secure throughput in the finite blocklength regime by finding and/or designing wiretap codes that can be proved to be best for their size. The project addresses the following three main research tasks: 1) characterize fundamental algebraic properties of optimally-secure (best) wiretap codes for simple channels; 2) find and design explicit, optimal, binary code structures for simple channels; and 3) expand best binary coding results to more difficult and realistic channel models and design optimal non-binary wiretap codes. It is anticipated that a host of currently known algebraic code structures will prove to be best for their size parameters. Generic algorithms will also be sought that produce best (or nearly-best) codes for blocklengths and dimensions where no known best algebraic structures exist. If successful, these results will transform finite blocklength wiretap code design. Such a collection of breakthrough results would empower communication experts to begin adopting physical-layer security codes in modern communication networks with full knowledge of the achievable rates of secure throughput for finite blocklength wiretap codes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project was originally a three-year effort (later extended to a fourth year) to understand optimal coding structures that can achieve both reliability to friendly parties in a communications network and security against information leakage to unintended recipients.  Codes that attempt to address both reliability and security are colloquially known as wiretap codes or secrecy codes.  The state of the art at the beginning of this project was a collection of codes that perform well as we consider their behavior in the limit as codes get large.  Large codes perform encoding and decoding tasks on several thousand bits at a time.  This project, however, was focused on optimal codes of fixed, and even small sizes, e.g., less than 50 bits.  These codes are likely to be useful in networks with battery-powered nodes and small payloads, such as the Internet of Things.  When coding at small blocklengths, optimal structures may also be more valuable, whereas optimal coding structures at large blocklengths may perform similarly to good constructions that are already known.

Some of the broader impacts of the project were accomplished in conjunction with the BYU IMMERSE program and the WE@BYU program.  BYU IMMERSE is a summer research endeavor for undergraduate students, wherein students join a research lab and participate in outreach activities.  This project funded seven undergraduate researchers in IMMERSE and continued to fund undergraduate research endeavors throughout the rest of the school year as well.  Three of these students went on to graduate school (one with the PI, and another in the same field as the PI).  WE@BYU is a Women in Engineering program at BYU that matched young undergraduate female students (freshmen and sophomores) in STEM with research laboratories.  Two of the undergraduate students joined the PI’s lab through this program and were later funded by the NSF grant.  An REU supplement aided in funding six of the seven undergraduate students.  Three of the seven students are female, and three different nationalities were represented in the group of undergraduate students.  This project helped the PI to grow a diverse research group.  The project also funded four graduate students (one who started the project as an undergrad) and paid for travel expenses for two of these students to attend top-tier conferences and network with other professionals in the field.  One of these graduate students has already graduated and produced a PhD dissertation.  Two additional PhD students are in the process of writing/defending their PhD work as of the writing of this report (early 2024).

The intellectual merit focus of the project produced four published journal papers and eight published conference papers, with an additional four papers under review at the time of writing this report (three journal papers and one conference paper).  These works now provide a set of results that characterize optimal wiretap coding structures in a variety of different settings.  Codes apply to simple and complex channel models, and real-world experiments have also been undertaken in indoor and outdoor wireless communication settings.  Most of the results are focused on coding schemes and theoretical proofs that show the optimal structure of various types of codes.  Some of these codes are well known and have been extensively studied for error control and their algebraic properties.  It is now known, thanks to this project, that these famous codes are also among a small set of known optimal coding structures for wiretap scenarios.  These codes are Hamming codes, simplex codes, and some Reed-Muller codes.  Algorithms for finding best codes over more complicated channel models were also discovered and published.  In one setting with noisy channels for both the intended and the unintended receiver, it is now known that one can start with an easy-to-find worst code with a certain set of parameters and use it as a starting point in an algorithm to find a best code under a different (target) set of design parameters, which is harder to find in general.  Other technical results include a complete decomposition of wiretap codes into their base structures, the tightest known lower bounds on secret throughput for finite blocklength codes, algorithms for optimal code design over erasure channels and bit-flipping channels and a set of real-world experiments over wireless channels.  Algebraic tools and proofs have been instrumental in attaining some of these results, whereas linear programming and gradient descent have been used in optimizations of code design as well.  We anticipate that these results wil be highly useful for system designers wishing to understand tradeoffs between optimality in code design and functionality in actual code constructions in real systems.
